Article.Abstract: Vaccines containing minigenes - isolated antigenic epitopes encoded by short open reading frames - can, under certain circumstances, confer protective immunity upon the vaccinee. Here we evaluate the efficacy of the minigene vaccine approach using DNA immunization and find that, to be immunogenic, a minigene-encoded epitope requires a perfect "Kozak" translational initiation region. In addition, using intracellular cytokine staining, we show that immunization with a plasmid encoding a full-length protein induces epitope-specific CD8(+) T cells which are detectable directly ex vivo, and constitute approximately 2% of the vaccinee's splenic CD8(+) T cells. In contrast, such cells are undetectable directly ex vivo in recipients of a minigene vaccine. Nevertheless, the minigene plasmid does induce a low number of epitope-specific CD8(+) T cells, which can be amplified to detectable levels by in vivo stimulation. Indeed, 4 days after in vivo stimulation (by virus infection), all vaccinated mice - regardless of whether they had been vaccinated with the minigene or with the full-length gene - had similar numbers of epitope-specific CD8(+) T cells. However, despite these strong responses at 4 days post-infection, recipients of the minigene vaccine showed no enhanced ability to limit virus replication and dissemination. We therefore observe a dichotomy; minigene vaccinees are not protected, despite the presence of strong virus-specific immune responses at 4 days post-challenge. We suggest that the protective benefits of vaccination exert themselves very soon - perhaps within minutes or hours - after virus challenge. If the vaccine-induced immune response is too low to achieve this early protective effect, virus-specific T cells will expand rapidly, but ineffectually, leading to the strong but non-protective response measured at 4 days post-infection. Thus, vaccine-induced immunity should be monitored very early in infection, since the extent to which these responses may later be amplified is largely irrelevant to the protection observed.
Article.ArticleTitle: Quantitative and qualitative analyses of the immune responses induced by a multivalent minigene DNA vaccine.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Neuropharmacology, CVN-9, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037, USA.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A plasmid encoding the full-length glycoprotein was used for immunization.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-specific cells were detectable when mice were immunized with plasmids encoding the full-length glycoprotein. However, responses were not detected at levels significantly above background after minigene immunization. When mice were immunized with plasmids encoding the full-length glycoprotein followed by in vivo LCMV restimulation, the responses were higher.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. This plasmid was used to immunize mice. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-specific cells were not detected at levels significantly above background after minigene immunization. However, when mice were immunized with plasmids encoding the full-length glycoprotein, the responses were markedly higher.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease
FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. This plasmid was used to immunize mice. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Splenic viral titers in immunized mice were not significantly different from the negative controls. A similar response was seen in the brain tissue after mengovirus challenge.

A minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. This plasmid was used to transfect K0, an SV-40-transformed cell line. The minigene-encoded epitopes required a perfect "Kozak" translational initiation region in order to be immunogenic. .

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were primed with a minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. An in vivo restimulation with LCMV was also administered. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-specific cells were not detected at levels significantly above background after minigene immunization alone, but were detectable after minigene immunization followed by an in vivo LCMV restimulation. A similar response was seen in a cytotoxicity assay. When mice were immunized with plasmids encoding the full-length glycoprotein followed by in vivo LCMV restimulation, the responses were similar.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized with vaccinia virus carrying this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. This plasmid was used to transfect K0, an SV-40-transformed cell line. The minigene-encoded epitopes required a perfect "Kozak" translational initiation region in order to be immunogenic. .

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were primed with a minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. An in vivo restimulation with Respiratory syncytial virus was also administered. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The response to the virus was accelerated and enhanced as a result of minigene priming.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were boosted twice at two week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were primed with a minigene cassette encoding this and two additional CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes, and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. An in vivo restimulation with Sendai virus was also adminitered. Splenocytes were restimulated in vitro for 4 days in the presence of the Sendai virus peptide FAPGNYPAL. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The target cells were K0, an SV-40-transformed cell line.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A minigene cassette encoding three CTL epitopes, two Th epitopes (including this epitope), and one B cell epitope was cloned into the NotI site of plasmid pCMV. This plasmid was used to immunize mice. Six weeks later, mice were infected with Vesicular stomatitis virus. .

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The assay examined the ability a T helper epitope to enhance the virus-specific neutralizing antibody response. Although antibodies were detected, no significant enhancement of anti-virus antibodies over control levels was detected.
